title: How to Make Hot Dog Buns

steps.headline: Dump all of the ingredients in, and choose the "dough" cycle.
Remove the dough when it's  done.
steps.description: Gently form it into a 'log' about 12" long.

steps.headline: Divide the dough into 12 equal pieces.
Shape them accordingly.
steps.description: For hot dog buns, you want cylinders, about 6" long.

steps.headline: Don't worry about making 'tops' and 'bottoms', or having the 'split' for your hot dog just yet.
steps.description: You can cut them after they're baked.

steps.headline: Place the dough forms on to a greased cookie sheet.
steps.description: Make sure you don't crowd them together too much, because they still have to rise.

steps.headline: Cover the buns with a clean dish towel, and let them rise for at least 20 minutes in a warm place.
Make sure your oven is fully preheated.
steps.description: Put the buns in the oven, then immediately turn the heat down to 350 °F (177 °C), to prevent them from burning. Bake 12-14 minutes.

steps.headline: Remove the buns, and let them cool.
Cut the buns after they are cool enough to handle.
steps.description: Make sure you don't go all the way through the hot dog buns, or they will get awfully messy.

steps.headline: Bring all milk and cream ingredients, just to a boil, over medium heat.
steps.description: Remove from heat, and let cool for ten minutes.

steps.headline: Meanwhile, stir together warm water and yeast in the stand mixer bowl, or a large mixing bowl and let stand until foamy, about 5 minutes.
steps.description: (If mixture doesn't foam, start over with new yeast.)

steps.headline: Add warm milk mixture, sugar, flour, and salt to your yeast mixture and mix at low speed.
steps.description: Scrape down sides of bowl as necessary, until flour is incorporated. Increase speed to medium and beat 6 minutes, or if mixing by hand, don't stop until you get a big dough-ball. Either way, the dough will still be sticky.

steps.headline: Transfer dough to a lightly oiled  bowl and turn to coat with oil.
steps.description: Cover with a clean kitchen towel and let rise in a warm place until doubled in size, or about 2 hours.

steps.headline: Grease baking pans.
steps.description: Punch down dough, then divide into 16 equal pieces.

steps.headline: Roll each piece of dough into a 6-inch-long log on a lightly floured surface.
steps.description: Space 8 logs evenly in each pan.

steps.headline: Loosely cover buns with oiled plastic wrap and let rise in a draft-free place at warm room temperature until buns just start to touch, 1 1/2 to 2 hours.
Preheat oven to 375 °F (191 °C)
Bake buns, turning pans halfway through, until tops are golden and undersides are golden brown, about 20 to 25 minutes.
steps.description: Cool in pans 10 minutes, then transfer to wire racks to cool completely.

steps.headline: Before using buns, separate them and cut each bun lengthwise down center (but not all the way through).
Enjoy!

text: With a Bread Maker Dump all of the ingredients in, and choose the "dough" cycle.  Remove the dough when it's  done. Gently form it into a 'log' about 12" long. Divide the dough into 12 equal pieces.  Shape them accordingly. For hot dog buns, you want cylinders, about 6" long. Don't worry about making 'tops' and 'bottoms', or having the 'split' for your hot dog just yet. You can cut them after they're baked. Place the dough forms on to a greased cookie sheet. Make sure you don't crowd them together too much, because they still have to rise. Cover the buns with a clean dish towel, and let them rise for at least 20 minutes in a warm place. Meanwhile, preheat your oven to 400 °F (204 °C). Make sure your oven is fully preheated. Put the buns in the oven, then immediately turn the heat down to 350 °F (177 °C), to prevent them from burning. Bake 12-14 minutes. Remove the buns, and let them cool.  Cut the buns after they are cool enough to handle. Make sure you don't go all the way through the hot dog buns, or they will get awfully messy. Without a Bread Maker Bring all milk and cream ingredients, just to a boil, over medium heat. Remove from heat, and let cool for ten minutes. Meanwhile, stir together warm water and yeast in the stand mixer bowl, or a large mixing bowl and let stand until foamy, about 5 minutes. (If mixture doesn't foam, start over with new yeast.) Add warm milk mixture, sugar, flour, and salt to your yeast mixture and mix at low speed. Scrape down sides of bowl as necessary, until flour is incorporated. Increase speed to medium and beat 6 minutes, or if mixing by hand, don't stop until you get a big dough-ball. Either way, the dough will still be sticky. Transfer dough to a lightly oiled  bowl and turn to coat with oil. Cover with a clean kitchen towel and let rise in a warm place until doubled in size, or about 2 hours. Grease baking pans. Punch down dough, then divide into 16 equal pieces. Roll each piece of dough into a 6-inch-long log on a lightly floured surface. Space 8 logs evenly in each pan. Loosely cover buns with oiled plastic wrap and let rise in a draft-free place at warm room temperature until buns just start to touch, 1 1/2 to 2 hours.  Preheat oven to 375 °F (191 °C)  Bake buns, turning pans halfway through, until tops are golden and undersides are golden brown, about 20 to 25 minutes. Cool in pans 10 minutes, then transfer to wire racks to cool completely. Before using buns, separate them and cut each bun lengthwise down center (but not all the way through).  Enjoy!
